column13: Fix basic.js and implement relayd for bridge configs
column20:
Basic.js should now behave correctly under all configuration types.
 Bridge configs are now implemented using relayd. Router IP should be DIFFERENT to AP subnet. I haven't changed the translation files to reflect this yet.

Please thoroughly test this patch, i've done my best to make sure it is ready.

column20:
I have successfully integrated bootstrap for a responsive design & layout. More information on the specifics are located here and well as my custom bootstrap build, and some images of the new design.
Caveats:

This phase 1 (personally my 4th complete code rework) is just for showing off possibilities and I am looking for as much feedback as possible. Also need people with screen readers to test to make sure everything works, any problems can be easily fixed.
Device name in sidebar header under logo isn't working, tried pretty darn hard to get it working. Must be something I'm missing.
Some of the very LONG pages like basic.sh, need some more tweaks and code cleanup which is no longer needed. Still would like wifi section on basic.sh to be broken into 3 parts.
Any features used were kept to IE8+ FF3+ All chrome/opera/safari versions for compatibility. Any hidden text will still be read on screen readers. Kept this to only the login screen currently.
Only javascript added was getting the sidebar to open when clicked on mobile, located at the bottom of the gargoyle header footer file.
You CAN flash over this build without having issues on 1.9.x builds. I backed up my settings as a precaution, as I suggest you do the same.
All *.sh/.css files can be modified on the fly on a running router without issues, so if you want to test changes or tweaks, modify away. Most of the *.js can be except common.js, which likes resetting your settings when modified.
I'm hoping to get this merged before or with 2.0.x builds. Sooner the input the sooner the changes can be applied.
theme.css is the primary .css file; any changes to it will override everything else. Thinking themes should have a default 'theme.css' file, possibly even a 'theme.js' since some people need to add custom js.
Yes, technically the sidebar menu is on the right side, and the content is on the left, why? because moving the code around caused it not to display the content on pages. Bootstrap lets you 'switch' columns which is what I am doing to get everything working. A better fix would be to put the sidebar menu before the actual content, but I couldn't get this working.
Some pages generate content via their .js equivalent file, however, I have yet to modify any ,js files outside the table.js file, so some tables and content looks off. These changes are planned, but currently waiting for feedback before I continue.
I have some idea's of making the menu look better since I currently think it looks bland.
There are still comments in the code which I used to debug the sidebar menu, currently just pointers and only can be seen in source
Technically you dont need anything other than the gargoyle package, so if you want to use this on a newer build of gargoyle, just copy folder over. Worse case, only the frontend (aka web interface) won't work, and a simple sysupgrade via terminal to flash to a working build fixes the issue.

column21:
First, I notice you have travis-ci stuff in there. If you have that working, it would be great if you commit that in a separate pull request, because I would merge that right away.
Second... this doesn't look like it's going to be backwards compatible with existing themes, of which there are many, which concerns me. You over-wrote the page layout for pretty much every page rather than altering CSS that works with the existing layout (or CSS that works with a modified layout and using javascript to modify it dynamically, which would also be perfectly fine and backwards compatible). I won't say no definitively, I might be persuaded, but when you're invalidating every theme that anyone has developed thus far... you need a very compelling reason to switch. What advantages do you feel are worth that in this implementation?
Also, how much space is this going to add (or subtract? maybe you've refactored it so the CSS is way more efficient? That would fall under "compelling reasons" above ;-) ) I'm about to drop support for 4M routers, but space is still at a premium.
Regardless of everything else, I do very much like the idea of allowing template files in the theme folder to make things more dynamic.
Finally -- while I don't care what logo you have in your own theme, the Gargoyle logo itself isn't going to change. I would consider changing the color, but the logo itself will always be the same, and will appear in the default theme, whatever it is, no matter what.

column21:
I will answer all the questions in the order you asked them.

Travis-ci isnt 100% working and i'll remove it from the pull request. Wasn't my main priority, and was trying to get it working.
I worked on this for 5-6 months, of which 2 months were dedicated to attempting to integrate bootstrap without issue into the current theme. I tried, however, because of the way bootstrap is designed, it would need more work arounds than was worth the time to do. There are 2 major pro's to the bootstrap design, 1. Being as its the most widely used responsive design out there, anyone who can develop a simple theme for your custom original theme, would have the easiest time to modify for this. Literally all the important css is in the theme.css, and overrides anything else. 2. Regardless of the fact that it is responsive, since I stuck to the default Bootstrap class's, ANYONE can easily generate a new theme file using: customizer ; I named mine theme.css but it spits them out as bootstrap.theme.css. Meaning even someone who doesn't know css design can goto that page change a few settings, download the new theme and rename the file and paste it into the Gargoyle theme folder and have a completely different color layout & design without needing to have any experience in html and css.
The size of the /www currently on the router is 1071KB. The size of Gargoyle theme folder is 97.5KB on the router. I believe this is around the same size was before or smaller, cant remember off the top of my head, maybe someone can du -h /www via ssh and let me know. This is with the optimized files + minified bootstrap.css. Some layout files can be modified further to shrink their size, removing unneeded code, specifically the large files (basic.sh comes to mind). From the internal.css and common.css files, I combined many of the same used code so that also saved space.
I was trying to play around with templating the header/footer file but didnt have the time to fully test it, would allow people like me to move the nav from sidebar to top for instance, with simple layout tweaks without having to recompile the whole firmware. Currently, no other Router firmware is modular like this... Would also allow people with the space to install larger themes that contain newer and more complicated js/css files like using morris.js. My main idea would be to make a new theme which supports only IE11+ latest browsers and move away from using js functions to html5, like removing cookies and input checks, html5 combines both to make it easier and faster since things can be cached and threaded to be crunching info in the background. But that's for another time.
Was a suggestion, will remove it and put up a cleaned version of the currently used one. No worries. And thanks for letting me know.

Another idea would be to move the internal.css and common.css to a /css folder within the theme folder since those are needed files keeping the Gargoyle theme folder clean, and adding a /js folder also, again allowing people to add js files, which the theme checks and auto loads if any found. Hmm reminds me of wordpress, maybe a config file within the theme that allows overrides to locations of files or compatibility information or something. I have too many ideas.

theme.css is the primary .css file; any changes to it will override everything else. Thinking themes should have a default 'theme.css' file, possibly even a 'theme.js' since some people need to add custom js.
Yes, technically the sidebar menu is on the right side, and the content is on the left, why? because moving the code around caused it not to display the content on pages. Bootstrap lets you 'switch' columns which is what I am doing to get everything working. A better fix would be to put the sidebar menu before the actual content, but I couldn't get this working.
Some pages generate content via their .js equivalent file, however, I have yet to modify any ,js files outside the table.js file, so some tables and content looks off. These changes are planned, but currently waiting for feedback before I continue.
I have some idea's of making the menu look better since I currently think it looks bland.
There are still comments in the code which I used to debug the sidebar menu, currently just pointers and only can be seen in source
Technically you dont need anything other than the gargoyle package, so if you want to use this on a newer build of gargoyle, just copy folder over. Worse case, only the frontend (aka web interface) won't work, and a simple sysupgrade via terminal to flash to a working build fixes the issue.

root@Gargoyle:~# du -h /www

2.5K    /www/hooks/login

945.0K  /www

So now it's actually smaller. ðŸ˜ƒ
The tools I used can actually be used on other packages also. I used nodejs(latest v5.x) + uglifyjs2 + uglifycss + https://compressor.io/.
Need to modify the build script to include new steps and update the old stuff. Currently, there is code in the (re)build for compressing the javascript with the no longer updated uglifyjs. Need to upgrade to uglifyjs2. There is no script to compress/minify the .css oddly enough. I manually uploaded the images to compressor.io and replaced them with the compressed versions. Going to move the wait_msg_background to css which will save space also.
The only difference in switches in uglifyjs2 is the input file is before the switches, not after like it is currently and the folder name is uglifyjs2.
Still looking for a way to minify .sh files, not sure if this would work: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/9907200/how-to-minify-obfuscate-a-bash-script

Sorry it's taken a while for me to reply... but if this is actually smaller, I think you've convinced me that this approach is good. I admit, I haven't built from this branch yet to see what your layout looks like (maybe post some screenshots?), so I can't comment on the specifics but updating the layout to use modern CSS tools (bootstrap) does make sense given that it's not adding space.
That said, this is a large pull request and merging it will not happen right away, as this is changing something fairly fundamental. I'm going to focus on getting the known-devices pull request in shape to merge first (this is long overdue), but I think this has a great deal of potential.

Minify bash code to duplicate my results:
npm install uglify-js -g && npm install uglifycss -g

uglifyjs2
for f in *.js; do short=${f%.js}; uglifyjs $f > ./min/$short.js -c -m; done
uglifycss
for f in *.css; do short=${f%.css}; uglifycss $f > ./min/$short.css; done
Run commands in respective js and css folders. Make sure "min" folder exists ðŸ˜‰
More info about tools:
https://github.com/mishoo/UglifyJS2
https://github.com/fmarcia/UglifyCSS

column21:
What is required to get this finished? And if i begin testing it on a working router, what do i need to watch out for at the moment?
BTW, theres a lot of whitespace issues due to your compiler (i assume?) and theres also some coding conventions that i'm not a fan of. I'm not sure everyone elses opinions but i feel that opening and closing braces for code should always have their own line, and that proper indentation should be followed. An example of where this has been utterly violated is overview.js

column13: Fix Archer C7 5GHz wifi. Add WRT1900ACS to builds.
column20:
Recently the ath10k driver was split so that the drivers and firmwares were seperate. The archer routers use the QCA988X series of chips and so we now need to include this. To support other devices in the future it may be necessary to include ath10k-firmware-qca99x0 and/or ath10k-firmware-qca6174
Add the WRT1900ACS (shelby) to the mvebu build target

column13: Samba fixes. New language Slovak-SK. Add temperature script. Bump Spectrum Analyser.
column20:
The "valid users =" clause breaks the guest access.
By removing it, all expected behaviour is retained.
If the user wants write access, they need to map the drive with authentication credentials. Otherwise they will just be allowed to access the drive without a prompt with the permissions given to the guest (r/rw). I have only commented the line out instead of removing it entirely to make the commit easier to revert in-case there is a usage case that i have not accounted for that does not behave correctly without the "valid users=" clause.
Preserve samba passwords across backups.
Introduce new language pack Slovak-SK.
Remove the temperature detection from overview page into a new external script. Allows for quicker and easier maintaining of existing and future models that support hwmon.
Add WRT1900ACS to the temperature detection list.
Update Spectrum Analyser plugin to 1.0.4. Fixes routers which don't strictly follow 802.11 IEEE standards for broadcasting their channel data

Hi,
This commit breaks to install "hostapd-utils" package because it contains the same name of file (wps) on the same path.
So "hostapd-utils" package needs the --force-overwrite switch to install it. But I think, because it's not bundled with Gargoyle, it's not relevant...

column20: missing ; on some end of lines.
column21: missing ; on some end of lines.

column20: missing ; on some end of lines.
column21:
This really isn't necessary.
In javascript the semicolons aren't necessary unless the two statements are on the same line. They're optional. Because I'm used to coding in C where the semicolons are required I have often put them in out of force of habit, but because they aren't required, there aren't any problems where they are absent. All of this goes through a js minimizer anyway, so it really doesn't matter.
You could make the argument that for purposes of having a consistent style it should get fixed... the problem being that this is much more widespread in the codebase than just what you adjust in this pull request. I'm going to close the pull request as-is because it doesn't really make things consistent, and I'm reluctant to head down the rabbit-hole of trying to do this everywhere.

column20:
default_small is similar to default, however it disables debugging features in kernel and strip kernel image and libraries to reduce the size. The result is that small routers with 4MB of Flash will have more spare space, allowing miniupnp package to be reactivated too (bringing UPnP support again, missing since Gargoyle 1.9).
The consequence of stripping kernel image and libraries is that the resulting firmware will not be compatible with packages from OpenWRT itself. Only the packages compiled with the firmware will be compatible. However this should not be a problem, all targets of this profile are routers with small Flash AND no USB support. So it generally impossible to install too many things on it.
This commit reactivates miniupnp for default profile too, since the target routers in this profile should be big enough to fit miniupnp.
Closes #524.

column21:
@lantis1008 suggested in issue #524 that it may be desirable to disable USB related plugins from this PR. It would be something like the patch below applied in targets/ar71xx/profiles/default_small/config file:
diff --git a/config_default_small b/config_default_small_nousb
index 0d82452..3597775 100644
--- a/config_default_small
+++ b/config_default_small_nousb
@@ -1398,8 +1398,8 @@ CONFIG_PACKAGE_plugin-gargoyle-i18n-Slovak-SK=m
 CONFIG_PACKAGE_plugin-gargoyle-i18n-Spanish-ES=m
 CONFIG_PACKAGE_plugin-gargoyle-initd=m
 CONFIG_PACKAGE_plugin-gargoyle-logread=m
-CONFIG_PACKAGE_plugin-gargoyle-minidlna=m
-CONFIG_PACKAGE_plugin-gargoyle-openvpn=m
+# CONFIG_PACKAGE_plugin-gargoyle-minidlna is not set
+# CONFIG_PACKAGE_plugin-gargoyle-openvpn is not set
 CONFIG_PACKAGE_plugin-gargoyle-ping-watchdog=m
 CONFIG_PACKAGE_plugin-gargoyle-pptp=m
 CONFIG_PACKAGE_plugin-gargoyle-spectrum-analyser=m
@@ -1411,10 +1411,10 @@ CONFIG_PACKAGE_plugin-gargoyle-theme-green=m
 CONFIG_PACKAGE_plugin-gargoyle-theme-horchata=m
 CONFIG_PACKAGE_plugin-gargoyle-theme-light=m
 CONFIG_PACKAGE_plugin-gargoyle-theme-xeye=m
-CONFIG_PACKAGE_plugin-gargoyle-tor=m
-CONFIG_PACKAGE_plugin-gargoyle-usb-printer=m
-CONFIG_PACKAGE_plugin-gargoyle-usb-storage=m
-CONFIG_PACKAGE_plugin-gargoyle-webcam=m
+# CONFIG_PACKAGE_plugin-gargoyle-tor is not set
+# CONFIG_PACKAGE_plugin-gargoyle-usb-printer is not set
+# CONFIG_PACKAGE_plugin-gargoyle-usb-storage is not set
+# CONFIG_PACKAGE_plugin-gargoyle-webcam is not set
 CONFIG_PACKAGE_plugin-gargoyle-webshell=m
 CONFIG_PACKAGE_plugin-gargoyle-wifi-schedule=m


I don't know what the rest of you prefers, I am happy either way and I understand why this packages may not be desirable when there is low Flash space (things like OpenVPN and Tor don't even install in those cases). However I think that some people will want those plugins even in routers with small Flash (because hardware mods allow you to add more Flash and/or USB, and it exists for the majority of these models).

column21:
I've updated the ar71xx/default profile, which is already what you would call the default small profile -- this profile is the fallback and it's mostly only 4M routers in here. 8M routers should probably be moved to ar71xx/usb (even if they have no usb port), as the default profile really is now optimized to make 4M routers work. If there are some routers that should be moved over to ar71xx/usb, based on having 8M (even if there is no usb port), please send a pull request for that.
I've added part, but not all of what you suggest here. I'm setting the options you suggest to strip out debugging info, but I'm not going to toggle CONFIG_STRIP_KERNEL_EXPORTS or CONFIG_USE_MKLIBS, which would mean that most if not all packages that you try to install on top of the original build won't work. My preference is not to re-enable miniupnpd and to keep these two options disabled to allow the installation of other packages if desired.
By the way, when comparing profiles you may find the config_diff script located in the dev-utils dir useful. If you run it on two config files it will show you the differences in packages and options enabled, regardless of the original order in the config file (where if you use regular unix diff the order of the options is going to matter and you'll see more differences than may really exist if only the order changes).

column21:
Could we have at least CONFIG_STRIP_KERNEL_EXPORTS? This way, every package that is not a kernel module should work (this may confuse users, though).
And well, bringing back miniupnpd was really my objective in this PR. Using Gargoyle vanilla without it is really bad for home routers.

column20:
Eric,
With the inclusion of this PR, this branch has now addressed issues 1-5 that we discussed on the forum by PM.
Issue 6 (horizontal vs vertical layout) is my next target.

Firstboot i18n page now updated
Menu collapse issue, i have made it collapse at the largest possible size that doesn't adversely affect desktop users.
If a desktop user shrinks their screen just before the cutoff point, and a particularly long menu item (Spectrum Analyser as the active page, for example) is on screen, it will wrap to next line. However unlike before, the text now aligns under itself rather than to the edge of its parent container.
i.e.
Â Â Â Â Â > Spectrum
Â Â Â Â Â Analyser
instead of...
Â Â Â Â Â > Spectrum
Analyser
Vertical menu spacing now more closely resembles original gargoyle
Device name font reduced significantly, and fixed so it actually works (whoops!)
"Router Management Utility" dropped rather than relocating. Happy to place under the logo if you would prefer?

There is also a handful of additional fixes thrown in there for longstanding issues such as:

Quotas wiping the crontab file
QOS Rule table first item being unmovable
Fix corrupted German translation plugin
Fix incorrect menu structure for spectrum analyser plugin

column21:
I see two remaining issues which are related, but they're kind of big: Splitting Controls to two lines, and font size. The motivation for addressing both is the same: the new gui seems to take up significantly more space than the old gui, even splitting things out into columns. On mobile it seems quite good, but now on desktops it seems rather clunky.
Right now, I have to scroll twice as far as before just to scroll down through all the controls in the Connection/Basic wireless section. Before they all fit on one screen. I think part of the issue in making things fit is that the new font size for the labels and controls is larger than it was before, which I don't think is a good idea.
I'd really like to go back to trying to having labels on the left and controls on the right instead of splitting between rows like the new gui is currently doing, at least for how everything is displayed to desktop users. Ideally, on horizontally constrained screens this would wrap, while on larger screens it would remain on the same line. On the status screen the labels and values are on the same line, and this seems like what I think would be best elsewhere as well.
Tonight and tomorrow I'm going to work on updating the formatting and font size of the labels/controls, focusing first on the Connection/Basic section.

The one thing that is not working for me is syslog
Pleas note that I haven't tested on any other routers
If there is any thing wrong with this pleas let me know I am a real noob at this stuff! :D

column13: plugin usb-printer: Additional fallback to generate USB printer name
column20:
If an USB printer neither provides Product nor SerialNumber tag, the
printer configuration scripts fail to generate a printer name and exits.
This change adds an additional fallback combining Vendor, ProdID, and
Rev tag to generate a printer name. These tags should be available for
all USB devices.
This change fixes #587

column13: cache_basic_vars.sh: fix channel's parsing for VHT160
column20:
Device: Linksys WRT3200ACM
root@Gargoyle:~# iw phy0 info
Wiphy phy0
max # scan SSIDs: 4
[...]
Supported Channel Width: 160 MHz
[...]
* 5180 MHz [36] (23.0 dBm)
* 5200 MHz [40] (23.0 dBm)
* 5220 MHz [44] (23.0 dBm)
[...]
This Linksys supports 160MHz channel width, current version of the script gives incorrect data in the tables:
nextCh.push(Width:); nextChFreq[Width:] = "SupportedMHz"; nextChPwr[Width:] = 160;
nextCh.push(36); nextChFreq[36] = "5180MHz"; nextChPwr[36] = 23;
nextCh.push(40); nextChFreq[40] = "5200MHz"; nextChPwr[40] = 23;
nextCh.push(44); nextChFreq[44] = "5220MHz"; nextChPwr[44] = 23;

column21:
I just committed an update that should address the issue I suspect you're encountering, but I have to reject your pull request.
The way I had it was a bit of a hack I admit, but your pull request makes the situation worse, not better. Some builds (the ones for larger routers with more space) use iproute2-full, others use iproute2-tiny and whichever is used, qos needs to link to it. Your change would kill some builds, those with iproute2-full.
The update I just added should dynamically check what is present, and use iproute2-full if it exists, otherwise iproute2-tiny.

column20:
This PR has 3 main changes

Reg Database update to latest via patch. Some countries have had more spectrum opened up and higher transmission powers enabled.
Make Gargoyle menu system collapsible
Enable collapsible menus on default theme

The previous implementation of the menu system meant that if you clicked one of the major menu items, it would take you to the first item in that sub category e.g. Clicking on Connection took you to Connection->Basic
This new set of changes makes the major headings expand and collapse to reveal their sub-menus. This change is particularly useful on mobile devices where the number of clicks required to get to a particular page was increased.
This has been implemented by making the links into "dummy anchors" i.e. "#" and the links all return false with their onclick event, meaning the URL never changes to include the dummy anchor, reducing confusion.
If a major heading has zero sub-menus, the old behavour is retained i.e. clicking on it will take you directly to it's linked page. A good example of this is the logout button.
As part of this change i also fixed the tab indentation of the entire file which was previously destroyed, and implemented proper tab indentation of the resulting HTML once passed through haserl. This makes the source code in the browser much easier to navigate.
Unfortunately due to this, the diff is a bit all over the place, so if you would like me to step through the changes in more detail i can arrange this. A good example of the type of change is found at Line 560 of the header_footer file.
Individual themes can turn on and off the collapsing behaviour by including a single (empty) txt file within the theme with the name collapseMenus.txt. This adds minimal (none?) overhead to the theme size.
A demonstration of the new behaviour can be seen here

column21:
I like the ability to navigate the menu without actually visiting the link.
However, what I don't like is that the way you've implemented this, (1) you have to click on a section to see what's in it, which means clicking doesn't actually open the section, and thus clicking doesn't do what you would expect and (2) when you do click and open a different section you can't see where you are at that moment anymore. I kind of expect to see the menu indicate what section/page I'm currently at.
One way to fix this might be if I didn't have to click at all, but rather if hovering over the button would expand it, and the menu then returned to the current section after I move the cursor away.
I'm not going to merge this as-is (though I cherry-picked the regdb update), and I'm very open to something like this, just not as-is due to the usabiltiy issues listed above. I'm going to leave the pull request open so that if you want you can add more commits based on my concerns, and I will  re-evaluate.

I'll revisit the useability.

column21:
I'm looking at whether using mouseover events is reliable and doesn't break interface.
Currently that's a no from my opinion. It makes the whole thing very jarring to use, not better.
To overcome this you'd need to apply smoothing to the menu opening.
There also needs to be a time delay function to reset the menu back to where you currently are.

column21:
Hi @ericpaulbishop
Please see/test the latest changes to this PR.
I have not done a build test, but have tested the code on a live router.
Changes:

Nav elements now have an ID assigned to them making them easier to find/manipulate in functions e.g. "Status" is the first major nav item so it is "nav_MAJ01_MIN00". "Overview" is the first minor nav item under Status so it is "nav_MAJ01_MIN01" etc.
On pageload, the nav state for that page is stored in a variable. I don't forsee this being a problem, but if it is it could be coded into the header/footer program itself
If the user moves their mouse away from the menu for > 1.2s, the menu will restore to it's original state. This action is cancelled if the user puts their mouse back onto the menu before the timer lapses.
As discussed, the "onclick" behaviour of the menu has now been changed to "onmouseover". I don't agree with this change and personally think it feels very clunky. Please spend a bit of time using this particular part and let me know your thoughts. It could maybe be solved by a slow transition applied to the menu, although i couldn't get this to work properly.

Please let me know of any feedback.
@tapper82 the onmouseover events should be ok for a screen reader. I navigated the menu using keyboard only and it operated as i expected.

column21:
Hmm... I see what you mean about the limitations of mouseover.
I'll admit, the onclick interface DOES work really well for mobile devices, it's just really non-intuitive for desktop users. Maybe the best thing to do is implement this with onclick, but make that only active at all for mobile users -- so for now, Desktop users get the old behavior, while mobile users get the new behavior with onclick.

column21:
I'm unsure how to achieve this without generating two Nav bars.
One to be displayed at desktop resolutions, and the other to be displayed on mobile.
Can you be swayed for allowing the desktop case new behaviour?
I agree that it is strange at first given what we are used to, but like most change, we can adapt with time.
My current thoughts are to return to implementation 1, with the menu returning back to its home state after the delay added in (you're 100% right about this one).

I tested the javascript though, and it seems to be working.

Ah, excellent point, thanks for pointing that out.
From what I saw, I think it probably does fail gracefully but I haven't tested it and even if it's ok now if we change something further it might not. I think the best solution  is to add a javascript flag that gets written by gargoyle_header_footer, and then tested before calling the javascript that handles the collapsible menus.

column21: Just committed a fix for this, and in doing so added a feature: theme-specific javascript. If a theme.js file is present in the theme directory, it gets automatically included by gargoyle_header_footer. I moved the call to the initialization code out of common.js and into the theme.js file for the default Gargoyle theme.

This new set of changes makes the major headings expand and collapse to reveal their sub-menus. This change is particularly useful on mobile devices where the number of clicks required to get to a particular page was increased.
This has been implemented by making the links into "dummy anchors" i.e. "#" and the links all return false with their onclick event, meaning the URL never changes to include the dummy anchor, reducing confusion.
If a major heading has zero sub-menus, the old behavour is retained i.e. clicking on it will take you directly to it's linked page. A good example of this is the logout button.
As part of this change i also fixed the tab indentation of the entire file which was previously destroyed, and implemented proper tab indentation of the resulting HTML once passed through haserl. This makes the source code in the browser much easier to navigate.
Unfortunately due to this, the diff is a bit all over the place, so if you would like me to step through the changes in more detail i can arrange this. A good example of the type of change is found at Line 560 of the header_footer file.
Individual themes can turn on and off the collapsing behaviour by including a single (empty) txt file within the theme with the name collapseMenus.txt. This adds minimal (none?) overhead to the theme size.
A demonstration of the new behaviour can be seen here
column21: Very cool. Went from a nice to have addition to a big value add.

column21:
Hi,
I'm not sure that these patches suit the larger gargoyle audience. They look to be very specific to a few routers, and a few scenarios.
My thoughts:

worried about your removal of the issinglesthernet checks in basic.js. The Gargoyle Pocket Router (when it was in the shop) is a single Ethernet device. Breaking functionality on a device sold by Gargoyle is not good.
your handling of VLAN switch config is not generic. It only applies to those particular devices
multiuser support, while I'm not disinclined to this, the way this one is implemented leaving a large security backdoor is a big no from me
removal of firstboot page means users aren't promoted to set language or change default password
I don't like the idea of having patches to the main gargoyle package. That seems hard to maintain

To me this seems like a very niche patch that would be better implemented in a forked repo by creating a new target and using the target/patches/ structure to apply these at build time

column20:
Simple Port Management patches will allow you to modify the WAN port.
This functionality is good for ISPs with IPTV.
In most cases, it's not necessary to install a switch at the customer.
column21:
`    I don't like the idea of having patches to the main gargoyle package. That seems hard to maintain
To me this seems like a very niche patch that would be better implemented in a forked repo by creating a new target and using the target/patches/ structure to apply these at build time`
I can periodically update the patches in my forked repository.
These patches provide advanced functionality of the standard system. Any functionality or change is exported to a separate patch and described. They are intended for use with custom build. The user can decide which patch wants to use and who does not.
The patches offer users with no experience an easy way to change basic things without losing their own time with a thorough examination of the system.
Please read the readme file:
https://github.com/mysticall/gargoyle/blob/master/spm/README.md

column21:
I am going to close this pull request, as I'm not willing to make such radical changes to the base system for such a niche application.
If you can figure out a way to do this as a plugin, I will reconsider merging it.
I would add that if you find that you can't do it as a plugin due to changes necessary in the basic section (which may be the case), if you can find a way to make it possible to preserve current functionality by default, but allow a plugin to modify certain sections of the basic page I would consider merging those changes to connection/basic. I know, that's not easy/straightforward, but if you want to go that route you might start with looking at how plugins can add sections to the login/landing page right now and do something similar in connection/basic.

column13: update uhttpd.crt and uhttpd.key for use with modern browsers
column20:
Some modern browsers like Chrome 58+ no longer matches the Common Name (CN) in certificates and make use of Subject Alternative Names (SAN) instead. Making SAN a mandatory field.
Due to this the previous certificates in use were recognized as invalid with the error net::ERR_CERT_COMMON_NAME_INVALID even after manually adding the Certificate Authority (CA) to trusted list.
see: Can not get rid of net::ERR_CERT_COMMON_NAME_INVALID error in chrome with self-signed certificates
Command used:
openssl req \
	-newkey rsa:2048 \
	-x509 \
	-nodes \
	-keyout uhttpd.key \
	-new \
	-out uhttpd.crt \
	-subj '/O=Gargoyle Router Management Utility/CN=Gargoyle' \
	-reqexts SAN \
	-extensions SAN \
	-config <(cat /etc/ssl/openssl.cnf \
		<(printf '[SAN]\nsubjectAltName=DNS:gargoyle.lan,IP:192.168.1.1')) \
	-sha256 \
	-days 3650

This also tries to address some of the issues in #531 (@m45t3r)

With this change, the certificate will now be termed as valid by the browser as long as:

the IP of the router running Gargoyle remains to the default 192.168.1.1
the CA is known on client system

Other things that should be done:

 adapt the above command for systems with openssl installed so that in case the default uhttpd.crt and uhttpd.key are deleted, the new auto-generated (through package/gargoyle/files/www/js/access.js#L160-L169) ones are not invalid.
 issue new certificates on IP address change

With this change, the certificate will now be termed as valid by the browser as long as:

the IP of the router running Gargoyle remains to the default 192.168.1.1
the CA is known on client system

Other things that should be done:

 adapt the above command for systems with openssl installed so that in case the default uhttpd.crt and uhttpd.key are deleted, the new auto-generated (through package/gargoyle/files/www/js/access.js#L160-L169) ones are not invalid.
 issue new certificates on IP address change

column13: set locale for banner creation for consistent dates
column20:
Set the locale for banner creation so that you get consistent dates
If the locale is not set, then the date format will be taken from
the system which will result in inconsistent dates.

column20:
Revert removal of "valid users" option
This was not tested thoroughly enough by me. Causes any valid user credentials to gain access to ALL shares, despite what access restrictions are in place
Change samba guest account to "nobody" from "root"
On Gargoyle it probably does not matter, but this is more conventional. If nobody account was compromised it has no valid login anyway
Add guest to valid users when guest access is selected
This seems to be required to work properly when the "valid users" option is reinstated.
column21:

On Gargoyle it probably does not matter, but this is more conventional. If nobody account was compromised it has no valid login anyway
Add guest to valid users when guest access is selected
This seems to be required to work properly when the "valid users" option is reinstated.

column20:
Add Iran Timezone translation to ZH-CN
Addresses part of #683
Fix the valid case for proofread functions. Instead of returning "black", return nothing so that the default colour for the theme takes over. This also stops people on the forums thinking their 5ghz network is "disabled" because it is a slightly different shade of grey to the 2.4ghz network.
(note for future, apparently the 5ghz network isn't being proofread. That's probably my fault)
Add TP Link Archer's to the button handler patch. This patch may need to be made more specific for different variations, but we can handle that in due time
is_tplink now looks for "TP-LI" at the beginning of the machine string as well.
Addresses #681
Add Quad9 DNS to UI as an option
https://www.quad9.net/#/about
Requested by forum users

column13: Allow for devices with no wireless capability
column20:
Please consider this a more comprehensive version of #682
If the device has no wireless capability (i.e. cached_basic_vars contains the minimal variables, and /etc/config/wireless is empty):

Removal all options except "Disabled" from wireless mode
Remove wireless WAN modes
Disable selection of wireless bridge/repeater

Add new function removeOptionFromSelectElementByValue to enhance existing functionality but allow us to be i18n safe
Closes #626

column21:
These are bits of code which we know are likely to fail and hence are placed inside "try catch" blocks.
In this method, the error is dealt with gracefully and the code and continue operating.
For example, we want to assign the SVG (graph) object from the bandwidth_distribution page to a variable so that we can use it. This SVG object takes a long time to load, and so at some early point in time, the object is not necessarily defined. We know this ahead of time, so we "try" to assign this object to the variable, and if it errors, we "catch" the error. In this case the catch is essentially to wait, and try again.
There is no problem here, and you should not have that option enabled in debugging mode unless you are trying to specifically highlight these types of scenarios.

My only comment is it might be better to make an x86 target, with default profile, and 86-64 be another profile underneath it.
Then we get both.
Only a suggestion though.
Oh and you need to provide an â€œimagesâ€ file as per other targets

Please include by default kmod-usb-hid - required for usb keyboard.
IMO also should be include - kmod-usb2/kmod-usb2-pci, kmod-usb3. Space is not problem so you can also include kmod-ath10k with firmware
There is a target alix is x86, but I do not know what it is  @lantis1008
ok, @obsy

@ericpaulbishop what happening with this patch?
I want to try it out

I may add this when after updating the new version of Openwrt but adding before then means supporting it in both the old Openwrt version and the new. So, this is on hold until the update is done (which I'm working on now)

One issue is that packages don't get grabbed correctly, and i haven't thought of an elegant solution yet.
in *-src/bin/packages there are 2 folders rather than the typical 1. This breaks the find logic in part of build.sh.
One possible solution would be to recursively copy all package files across, and concatenate the Packages manifest etc files together. I am unsure how the signature would be treated in this case
I've created a branch for rebasing this to 1.11.x (lantis1008@a1602a9) but i haven't been able to run test it, only compile test. I also haven't included any of the patches or additional requests from this thread at this stage. Hopefully it is a good reference for the future changes.

Please close in favour of #774
If you need to make any changes please base them on the new developments.
Thanks.

column13: Add new bandwidth monitor (month) with variable reset time
column20:
This option allows users to spin-up a new monthly bandwidth monitor that resets on the day they choose. This will allow them to align the monitoring with their ISPs reset dates (a highly requested feature).
Feature could be extended easily to allow any interval/reset time custom monitor, however it is currently written with months hardcoded for this particular purpose.
column21:
This option allows users to spin-up a new monthly bandwidth monitor that resets on the day they choose. This will allow them to align the monitoring with their ISPs reset dates (a highly requested feature).
Feature could be extended easily to allow any interval/reset time custom monitor, however it is currently written with months hardcoded for this particular purpose.

column13: Fix restrictions applied to single IPs not working
column20:
The iptables syntax changed a while ago to move the ! ahead of the command rather than ahead of the parameter. Most of Gargoyle appears to be compliant with this, and this one may just be a remnant from long ago. Unsure how long it has been broken.
Closes #694

Fix client disable checkbox not doing anything
Implement verify-tls script to enable fast/easy temporary revocation of certificates

Client Verified

Tue Dec 19 20:57:55 2017 daemon.notice openvpn(custom_config)[26205]: 192.168.0.209:49488 VERIFY SCRIPT OK: depth=0, C=??, ST=UnknownProvince, L=UnknownCity, O=UnknownOrg, OU=UnknownOrgUnit, CN=client1, name=client1, emailAddress=client1@.com

Client Rejected

Tue Dec 19 20:54:08 2017 daemon.warn openvpn(custom_config)[26205]: 192.168.0.209:33403 WARNING: Failed running command (--tls-verify script): external program exited with error status: 1

Closes #689

Properly generate single .ovpn file (clean up the format)
Allow individual clients to have their gateway address set to "vpn_gateway"


Closes #690

Fix default cipher not changed to AES-265-CBC

Closes #668

Implement Certificate Revocation List (CRL) to allow us to permanently revoke certificates that are no longer required and therefore no longer valid
Fix the random domain for email not being created properly. This makes the DN unique which makes revocation cleaner

Certificate Valid
Thu Jan  4 16:30:41 2018 daemon.notice openvpn(custom_config)[20897]: 192.168.0.1:61077 CRL CHECK OK: C=??, ST=UnknownProvince, L=UnknownCity, O=UnknownOrg, OU=UnknownOrgUnit, CN=client1, name=client1, emailAddress=client1@wcsvrlvajsjprxz.com
Thu Jan  4 16:30:41 2018 daemon.notice openvpn(custom_config)[20897]: 192.168.0.1:61077 VERIFY OK: depth=0, C=??, ST=UnknownProvince, L=UnknownCity, O=UnknownOrg, OU=UnknownOrgUnit, CN=client1, name=client1, emailAddress=client1@wcsvrlvajsjprxz.com

Certificate Revoked
Thu Jan  4 16:36:02 2018 daemon.notice openvpn(custom_config)[20897]: 192.168.0.1:65391 CRL CHECK FAILED: C=??, ST=UnknownProvince, L=UnknownCity, O=UnknownOrg, OU=UnknownOrgUnit, CN=client1, name=client1, emailAddress=client1@wcsvrlvajsjprxz.com (serial 01) is REVOKED

Closes #688

Fix unchecking of "Use Custom MAC Address" not actually returning the interfaces MAC to the default value

Closes #711

Fix Openvpn Status (openvpn_connections.sh) not hiding when server is disabled.
Fix Openvpn not pushing new routes for the server by restarting the server when a client with a routed subnet is added/deleting. This will cause a momentary loss of connection for other clients, but they should all self re-establish. The reconnection period is equal to the keepalive setting (currently defaults to 180 seconds)

Closes #691

column21:
@ericpaulbishop i'm about to try and tackle #688 next
In order to do this, i'm going to want to revoke certificates (rather than just deleting them).
Have figured out how to do this [1], but i need an intact index file for the certificate database.
We are currently generating the certs/keys in /tmp/randomdir and then removing that dir afterwards, rather than operating at /usr/lib/easy-rsa.
Is there a reason for this? Or is it purely a flash space conscious action?
It may not matter as i may be able to rescue the needed files and store them in /etc/openvpn with everything else and rebuild the folder as required (similar to what is already being done). This will be my next experiment based on your answer.

column21:
Sorry for the delay on answering this: Writing to the /tmp/[random] dir is a flash space consideration and a consideration of the fact that reading/writing to a ramdisk (/tmp) is usually much faster than to flash.
You've marked this patch set "NOT READY FOR MERGE", so when you feel it is ready for merge, please specifically let let me know here in the comments, otherwise I'll wait.

@ericpaulbishop
This is now ready for merging.
I've done my best to test Server configurations, but have done no client tests. As far as i can tell, clients should be unaffected.
Anyone else that wants to test please feel free and provide feedback. @ispyisail you seem to know a fair bit about openvpn, your input would be most appreciated.
I would mark this config as incompatible with previous versions. People should rebuild their servers and regenerate certificates where practical.

column20:
Fixes due to changes in Openwrt infrastructure arrangements.
Depending on how the dust settles, can drop patch 031 (or rework it).

Bump CC to latest
Fix (and rework) build script

Remove the notion of pulling "trunk". We now set the openwrt_commit to nothing to pull latest from any branch
Add ability to specify a branch for packages



We can use this same script with 17.01 reasonably easily with the following example:
-branch_name="Chaos Calmer"
+branch_name="17.01"
-branch_id="chaos_calmer"
+branch_id="openwrt"
-packages_branch="for-15.01"
+packages_branch="lede-17.01"
-openwrt_commit="e6fbf31baae41b618ff333f3ae55ff032333bd6a"
+openwrt_commit="444add156f2a6d92fc15005c5ade2208a978966c"
Patch 031 would need to be dropped in this case.
column21:

column20:
Give ddns_updater the ability to pass control to an external "helper script"** for services which require complex updates (i.e. can't be done by a simple GET request to a special URL)
Update cloudflare service provider to use APIv4 (original API is now deprecated and was not working) using helper script (relies on curl + ca-certificates-combined)
GUI will warn user if they are trying to setup a provider which relies on a helper script and they do not have it installed
Fix response matching always triggering Success even if it actually failed

Other services that need to be updated in this way include:

GoDaddy
No-IP (maybe? need to test)

Happy to give you access to my API key etc for testing if you want/need.

**Helper Scripts will be bash scripts stored in the /usr/lib/ddns-gargoyle/ folder
Required variables will be set in the config and passed IN ORDER to the script
The script will always be passed LOCAL_IP, FORCE_UPDATE and VERBOSE as the final 3 variables
Scripts should be written with this in mind
Scripts should return:

Update failed; exit 3
Update not needed; exit 4
Update successful; exit 5
This aligns with ddns updater itself and these are the expected values

column13: Fix graph overflow in Chromium browsers
column20:
Graphs on the bandwidth page were overflowing their bounds on some browsers (seems to be Chromium isolated).
From investigation it looks like the browser was occasionally ignoring the division by 100 when calculating the bounds of the graph. By putting this operation in brackets, it appears to fix this behaviour.
Behaviour has only been reported in the last few weeks/months so some upstream update must have caused this. Looked ok to me in the past.
Have not spotted the behaviour on any other graphs, but if it is found to be a problem a similar fix can probably be investigated.



Variable
Expected Result
Actual Result




graphRightCoor
680
68000


graphBottomCoor
510
51000

column13: Fix popup window centering on edit pages
column20:
An attempt to fix edit popup pages centering by making use of the window properties described below and some minor code changes:

Window.outerWidth/outerHeight gets the width/height of the outside of the browser window. It represents the width/height of the whole browser window including sidebar (if expanded), window chrome and window resizing borders/handles.

Browser compatibility should not be a problem. Although, Microsoft Edge seems to do it's own thing when it comes to window positioning, which is a known issue apparently. Works fine with every other browser I tested it with (Chromium based, Firefox, etc).
Screenshots (Before/After)

column13: Add basic HTTPS sniffing capability to Gargoyle
column20:
Make Gargoyle Webmon (Status->Web Usage) more useful by allowing it to see the destination URL (FQDN only) of **most HTTPS requests.


Make Gargoyle Weburl more useful by allowing it to match the destination URL (FQDN only) of **most HTTPS requests. Can now place restrictions on websites with reasonable levels of success.


Increase flexibility of make_iptables_rules (and fix a bug i introduced 2 months ago unknowingly)


Fix a missing reject line for URL matching


Add in Turkey Time as per change in the local timezone (2016, we missed it by a bit)


** This is achieved by leveraging the Server Name Indication (SNI) extension of the TLS1.2 standard in HTTPS authentication. The host name (e.g. example.com) is served in the clear in the packet so that the server knows which certificate to send back to the client. The path (e.g. /foo.html) is only sent once the transmission is fully encrypted. That is to say, we can only match the domain of HTTPS traffic.
SNI is supported by all major browsers and has been gaining proliferation since the mid 2000's.

My thought is that we would handle the problem by matching DNS requests (and we may still add that at some point to block other types of traffic), but this is better in that it preserves the exact same functionality as before.

You don't need to rebase. Checkout the commit before the proposed changes and create a new branch. Then use the git cherry-pick command to add the commits you want to the new branch. Merge in the my master branch to make sure it will merge ok, and then send a pull request for that branch.
I'll add that your proposed changes other than the alt DHCP gateway look good, and I'll merge the pull request with those. I need to take a closer look at the alt DHCP gateway proposal before I decide on that one.

column13: Add common CSS class for all "Add" buttons and some minor fixes
column20:
Since there are currently ~30+ "Add" buttons spread throughout the system (among pages and templates), assigning a common CSS class (i.e. btn-add) would make it easier to apply a distinct style and maintain the look & feel consistency through them all.
This goes in line with the recently added custom CSS classes for common table buttons (e.g. btn-edit, btn-remove, etc).
Changelog

Add common CSS class for all "Add" buttons inside pages and templates
Fix disabled class not being assigned to QoS "Comment" button
Minor clean up of unused/outdated HTML code

column21: Thanks. My guess is that this has to do with the fact that the getopt() function used to parse options is defined in the standard C library, and the newest version of OpenWRT uses musl instead of uclibc as its standard C library implementation.

column20:
Rewrite of Switchinfo.sh to be device independent

Should now support any device with a valid /etc/board.json file with a mapping between the logical and physical ports
Can support > 4 LAN ports (although >9 may require more cosmetic testing, cross that bridge later)
Admittedly have only tested on a few devices, but don't foresee any major hassles

Openvpn Updates

Remove BlowFish ciphers. These have been found to be insecure (see SWEET32 Birthday attacks)
Remove all references to keysize parameter (was only required with ciphers like BF)
Set default Cipher to AES-256-CBC (should be used for backwards compatibility concerns with older clients). There is an option to allow outdated clients to negotiate the use of BF ciphers, however i have chosen not to allow this as it is to be completely removed in following updates of OpenVPN
Add new ciphers AES-128/256-GCM (note that newer clients will negotiate with server and upgrade cipher to AES-256-GCM if capable on both ends)

column20:
This is a revisit of #469 (now closed) which was initially rejected, and then reopened on condition of changes requested.

Allows the user to select the country they are in for regulatory purposes. The default option ensures regulatory compliance in all countries

Through the use of a new tool Gargoyle-IP-Query (leveraged off existing code from ddns_updater), we can attempt to detect the GeoIP location of the user.
The user will be allowed to set a wireless country setting under the following conditions:

A GeoIP location has been successfully detected (requires internet connection)

For this reason, this option is not available at firstboot, but will show up the first time Connection -> Basic is loaded after an internet connection is available


If the country setting has been previously set, it cannot be set again

This includes routers which now ship with the country setting by default



The user is also presented with a large text block:

Gargoyle has attempted to determine your geographical region. If this is not correct, it is strongly recommended to leave this setting as World (Default).
Setting this value incorrectly may lead to you violating regulatory standards in your region. If in doubt, choose World (Default) which is legal in all regions.
By setting your country correctly, you may be allowed to use additional channels, higher transmit power or wider channel widths.
Note: You may only change this setting once.

Would appreciate testing here. I believe i have covered most bases.
If this still does not fit the brief, please let me know what you would like to see differently.

column21: Thanks for pointing this out, I'm taking a look now
WRT32X support currently broken.
Reopening with latest 18.06 and fixed wrt32x support

column20:
Bump Openwrt revision to 18.06-rc1
Update ca-certificates to latest and tell build system that it provides ca-bundle (more below)
Update mvebu update strings (these are now bin files) and tempinfo for WRT32X
Patch the default Openwrt SSID to "Gargoyle"
Handle wifi device busy status in Spectrum Analyser plugin (this is caused by attempting to scan on a DFS channel which is not allowed)
Add sha1sum to mvebu. usb_storage relies on it (in particular /etc/init.d/share_users). This could be rewritten to use a different sha algorithm but it is simpler to just reinclude sha1sum for now.
Fix another ar71xx oversized image crash
Stop cross-contamination between build profiles
Update ath10k_large profile images

I have provided a temporary solution for ca-certificates-combined. It is perfectly valid, but we could do a few other things:

Rename local package to "ca-bundle"
Drop local package in favour of upstream
Leave this solution as it is
column21:
Bump Openwrt revision to 18.06-rc1
Update ca-certificates to latest and tell build system that it provides ca-bundle (more below)
Update mvebu update strings (these are now bin files) and tempinfo for WRT32X
Patch the default Openwrt SSID to "Gargoyle"
Handle wifi device busy status in Spectrum Analyser plugin (this is caused by attempting to scan on a DFS channel which is not allowed)
Add sha1sum to mvebu. usb_storage relies on it (in particular /etc/init.d/share_users). This could be rewritten to use a different sha algorithm but it is simpler to just reinclude sha1sum for now.
Fix another ar71xx oversized image crash
Stop cross-contamination between build profiles
Update ath10k_large profile images

I have provided a temporary solution for ca-certificates-combined. It is perfectly valid, but we could do a few other things:

Rename local package to "ca-bundle"
Drop local package in favour of upstream
Leave this solution as it is

column21:
@ericpaulbishop
Please see the following Google Sheet
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1E44rmp-F6B5P0W6TQ1GNmVFxjCIYCv88BYAqyuSlAAY/edit?usp=sharing
Devices highlighted in Green have been successfully compiled under the current code base.

I propose that devices labelled Tiny (4mb flash) be removed from the picture entirely.
There's some reasonably popular routers in the USB profile which aren't compiling. I think the kernel is exceeding capacity (rather than the rootfs), as i tried removing openvpn as a default package from USB and got no further. Can either:

Turf these as well
Move them to default and see if they compile?


Are there things that don't need to be in here that have been forgotten or aren't optimised correctly? I admit to not knowing too much in this area. I tried to pull IPV6 out but as you said, we have a few dependencies on it these days. It also seems to be much more tightly integrated into the Kernel.

column21: As requested on forum

column20:
wol is a REALLY old package which doesn't even seem to compile anymore on some targets.
Rather than patching it to work on those targets, switch to etherwake, which is available upstream (but frozen in this local repo for continuity) and has a smaller footprint.
column21:
wol is a REALLY old package which doesn't even seem to compile anymore on some targets.
Rather than patching it to work on those targets, switch to etherwake, which is available upstream (but frozen in this local repo for continuity) and has a smaller footprint.

column20:
Default CRL expiry is 30 days which is not practical for how Gargoyle is used. One option would be to create an auto-renewal script, but this may not be reliable.
There appears to be no immediate drawback to extending the CRL out to a long time period.
column21:

column20:
This pull request is based on #764.
Update ramips/mt7620 profile to Openwrt 18.06.1
Merged usb_mt7620 and usb_mt7620_mt76, since there was virtually no difference left in openwrt 18.06.1. Added mmc support, since some of the routers have micro sd card reader inside, and the packages do not take up much space.
The config file was generated by 'make custom'. From the menuconfig the following were chosen:
Target System:
Mediatek Ralink MIPS
Global Build Settings ->
Select "Compile with support for patented functionality"
Administration -> Gargoyle Web Interface ->
Select gargoyle, gargoyle-i18n, plugin-gargoyle-i18n-English-EN,
plugin-gargoyle-openvpn, plugin-gargoyle-usb-printer,
plugin-gargoyle-usb-storage, and leave the rest as "m"
Kernel modules -> Other modules ->
Select "kmod-sdhci-mt7620"
Network ->
plugin-gargoyle-ddns-cloudflare as "m"
Then save the config (twice, because for the first time several commented
ar71xx modules are included, as well), then quit from menuconfig and CTRL+C.
Target ramips needed to be patched so build would not fail if the generated image is too big. Profile usb_mt7620 has all the profiles now that compile without problems. Dropping the micro sd support does not add any new devices into the list.
Created mt7620_mini profile, which only contains the gargoyle web interface and the internationalization package. All the rest from above are included as modules. Three devices do not compile, even with internationalization dropped:
-ex2700
-vonets_var11n-300
-wt3020-4M
Replaced dependency of msmtp on ca-bundle to ca-certificates-combined.

column21:
Is it zyimage failing or is it check-size?
If it's zyimage i think you'll want to do something like the following:
define Build/zyimage
         if [ -e "$@" ] ; then \
                  $(STAGING_DIR_HOST)/bin/zyimage $(1) $@ \
         fi; \
         echo ""
endef

column21:
Ok, so actually that was not the only error, there was also one in pad-to. However, the if-then version did not work, no matter which way I tried. In the end, I just put a semicolon at the end of the respective lines, and added an extra echo "" to make sure to return 0 exit code.
In fact, I am not sure why we do all the if-then magic. Openwrt makes sure to delete the too large files, so all we really need is to have exit code 0 everywhere for the run to continue. That can be achieved if we concatenate the relevant lines by adding ;\ to the end of each line, and finish with a command that returns 0 exit code always (echo ""). This should be enough.
Am I missing something?

column21:
Ok, I think I have it now. 30 devices out of 75 compile with openvpn, usb and micro sd support. Dropping the micro sd support does not help in getting more devices. I created an mt7620_mini profile, which essentially only contains the gargoyle web interface with English internationalization. I guess this way everyone can decide what is more important to them: usb or openvpn, and then they can install whichever they like and have the space for. 3 devices do not compile even with this bare minimum, so they cannot run gargoyle.
Some testing is still in order, before I remove the Do not merge flag.
Also, I would welcome any suggestions on how to clean up the history, etc. E.g. if you simply want one commit instead of many (on top of #764 of course), I don't mind squashing them and rewriting the log.
I am not sure about the if-then situation mentioned above. If it is needed, I can try to make all patch changes always (or never) using if-then, but I am not sure if that is necessary. Right now the patches seem to work for these two targets..

column20:
This pull request is based on #764.
Update ramips/mt7620 profile to Openwrt 18.06.1
Merged usb_mt7620 and usb_mt7620_mt76, since there was virtually no difference left in openwrt 18.06.1. Added mmc support, since some of the routers have micro sd card reader inside, and the packages do not take up much space.
The config file was generated by 'make custom'. From the menuconfig the following were chosen:
Target System:
Mediatek Ralink MIPS
Global Build Settings ->
Select "Compile with support for patented functionality"
Administration -> Gargoyle Web Interface ->
Select gargoyle, gargoyle-i18n, plugin-gargoyle-i18n-English-EN,
plugin-gargoyle-openvpn, plugin-gargoyle-usb-printer,
plugin-gargoyle-usb-storage, and leave the rest as "m"
Kernel modules -> Other modules ->
Select "kmod-sdhci-mt7620"
Network ->
plugin-gargoyle-ddns-cloudflare as "m"
Then save the config (twice, because for the first time several commented
ar71xx modules are included, as well), then quit from menuconfig and CTRL+C.
Target ramips needed to be patched so build would not fail if the generated image is too big. Profile usb_mt7620 has all the profiles now that compile without problems. Dropping the micro sd support does not add any new devices into the list.
Created mt7620_mini profile, which only contains the gargoyle web interface and the internationalization package. All the rest from above are included as modules. Three devices do not compile, even with internationalization dropped:
-ex2700
-vonets_var11n-300
-wt3020-4M
Replaced dependency of msmtp on ca-bundle to ca-certificates-combined.
column21:
What I can do is: do a make custom with CONFIG_BUSYBOX_DEFAULT_SHA1SUM enabled, and see how much of the config file changes. Then I can add it as a last commit, and it can be easily dropped if not needed, or whatever. This of course doesn't solve similar issues later on, but maybe let's do one step at a time.
I thought some more about the history:
I think the cleanest solution would be that commit c345474 is squashed into your commit 41c0535, but that would mean rewriting the history of the commits of your PR.
That is either you do it in your PR and I rebase this PR (I would prefer it), or I do it here, but then your PR and this one would be out of sync.

column20:
This seems to have been broken since the dawn of time? The epoch timestring at the beginning of all files read by this function are (unexpectedly) interpetted as valid ip addrs, and so the last backup is never stored. The index also always appears to have been off by 1, and was leading to a segfault as the array went out of bounds.
Make an assumption that the first part of the file is ALWAYS a timestring, and fix the index issue

column20:
Sendmail is now a separate utility (via symlink)
minidlna was starting before usb_storage was bringing up the external devices which would result in an empty database
Update ramips.default for 1.11.x
Fix WDS not applying properly to dualband devices (Closes #393)
Break usb-storage into two separate plugins to allow for minimal size builds
Break DDNS, QoS, WOL, miniupnpd into Gargoyle Plugins
Major rework of all configs to shrink builds (results in more than 30 devices returning to the build for ar71xx alone!)
Switch back to Openssl as SSL library for all packages to remove need for multiple SSL libraries

Minimal builds (mostly ar71xx.default/usb, some others) now have DDNS, QoS, WOL, miniupnpd and the ability to make network shares for attached USB drives excluded from the base firmware. This allows us to build a firmware small enough to fit on these devices. The user can then plug in a USB stick, setup an external plugin_root or extroot, and reinstall all functionality required from the plugin repository.
To assist with this, any function that is now "missing" is clearly marked with a message prompting the user that an additional plugin will be required to restore this function.

column13: Fix new plugins not appearing in menus on default install
column20:
Also fix ar71xx build errors to do with variants of usb-storage plugin.
Because we flip flop between them being included and modularised between each profile, it seems to get a bit confused and cause dependency errors. Splitting them into completely separate packages fixes the issue.
Also cleanup a syntax error which was causing clean_ipkg_partial to do nothing
Also update atheros to 1.11.x
Also update alix to 1.11.x and move it under x86 as a profile rather than a target
Also drop all references to madwifi/atheros drivers

column20: Not adding key-direction to config file
column21:
Is this a good idea?

From what I understood it is possible to omit the key direction, which will result in bidirectional use of keys: one HMAC and one for encryption and decryption.


Alternatively is it possible to configure altering values between 0 and 1 on the server and the client. (e.g. on the server 0 and on the client 1, or the other way around). Which causes the use of 4 distinct keys (HMAC-send, cipher-encrypt, HMAC-receive, cipher-decrypt).

column20: Not adding key-direction to config file
column21:
Unless the option has changed, you can set key-direction = 0,1, or bidirectional. This is what the script currently does.
If bidirectional is no longer explicitly stated then another change is required to do that.
Iâ€™d need to double check behaviour again but I think we already use the 4 way encryption.

column20: Not adding key-direction to config file
column21:
Just as a follow-up:

OpenVPN changed the key-direction parameter so it is now part of tls-auth i.e. tls-auth $file $keydirection

If $keydirection is omitted, bidirectional is used


Gargoyle sets the server to use key-direction 0 here
Gargoyle sets the client to use key-direction 1 here
When generating the single .ovpn file for clients, we interpret the Gargoyle settings and either set it as bidirectional, or as the corresponding 0 or 1 here

So behaviour is solid in my opinion.
HOWEVER, i do not know if the bidirectional symbol is still valid, or whether you omit it entirely in this case. I'm seeing conflicting reports on this.
I implemented it based on the FAQ here

column13: Fix fetching bw data which requires multiple runs
column20:
@obsy Can you please review this change? I'd normally just push it straight through but it's a bit of a hairy one.
Symptom: Users reported here that the High Resolution 15m graphs would only show some IP addresses after a period of time.
Problem: It appears that once the data in this monitor gets large enough that it can no longer be fetched in a single query, it is failing to do so.
The main cause of this is that the buf which we are sending back into the socket has now been filled with response data which is in a different format.
Solution: The quickest solution to this is to zero out the buffer and set it up again for the next request Lines 449-463
Problem: The next issue that becomes apparent is that we are expecting the request_index to be at buf+4 Line 382, however in the response it is at buf+5 Line 1716.
Solution: The easiest solution to this is to keep track of the index in a separate variable Line 445
Problem: With these two problems fixed, it then becomes apparent that there is a logic fail which causes the data to be overwritten each time because we never indicate that we have successfully initialized the data.
Solution: Toggle the flag Line 436

column13: Handle devices with wan_dev network section
column20:
@obsy can you please check this solution.
Reference:

Add to list: on some platform default mac addresses extracted from eeprom are stored in wan_dev/lan_dev section, not wan/lan itself. "Use Custom MAC Address:" should set mac in wan_dev section (if exists).

network.lan=interface
network.lan.type='bridge'
network.lan.ifname='eth0.1'
network.lan.proto='static'
network.lan.ipaddr='192.168.1.1'
network.lan.netmask='255.255.255.0'
network.lan.ip6assign='60'
network.lan_dev=device
network.lan_dev.name='eth0.1'
network.lan_dev.macaddr='d4:6e:0e:d0:49:68'
network.wan_dev=device
network.wan_dev.name='eth0.2'
network.wan_dev.macaddr='d4:6e:0e:d0:49:69'

Couple of things i'm not sure on, and would be good if you could test/confirm:

Is it necessary to delete wan_dev sections if we delete the main wan section. E.g. lines 154 and 160 (and others). If the wan_dev section causes no issues when it is present, then we will leave it. Definitely concerned about the implications when using wireless or usb protocols for wan
I think gargoyle_header_footer also needs updating (line 945) although it will usually work without it anyway as the mac is sourced directly from the interface. But would be good to add as an extra check. Can you please confirm it works ok as it is, and your opinion on whether it should be modified (i think yes)?
I've done nothing with lan_dev. Do you foresee anytime we need to do this?

Is it necessary to delete wan_dev sections if we delete the main wan section. E.g. lines 154 and 160 (and others). If the wan_dev section causes no issues when it is present, then we will leave it. Definitely concerned about the implications when using wireless or usb protocols for wan
I think gargoyle_header_footer also needs updating (line 945) although it will usually work without it anyway as the mac is sourced directly from the interface. But would be good to add as an extra check. Can you please confirm it works ok as it is, and your opinion on whether it should be modified (i think yes)?
I've done nothing with lan_dev. Do you foresee anytime we need to do this?
column21:
no. The wan_dev section can remain even if wan does not exist or wan is qmi proto.
check later.

column13: Fix guest network on mvebu devices
column20:
On mvebu devices with the 88W8964 wireless chip, the MAC address of any VAP must be within the mask 'FD:FF:FF:FF:FF:F0' of the first registered MAC on the interface (usually an AP). If we don't do this, the firmware will reject the packets, and we will be either unable to connect to the AP or the VAP depending on which order they got registered in.
Not all mvebu devices are prone to this error, however testing for the specific wireless chipset would be more difficult and this behaviour will not adversely affect the other devices in this target.
The getRandomMac function has a new wrapper getRandomMacWithMask, which allows us to limit the variability of these random macs produced. As a result of this limitation, we now also check that the (not so) randomly generated mac is indeed unique to the other existing interfaces, to avoid us ebtables blocking our entire LAN into oblivion.
I've also altered the getRandomMac function and provided a slightly more robust explanation about why hostapd was rejecting certain mac addresses, and given us the ability to generate them anyway if you might need to do so in the future.
References:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MAC_address
https://github.com/kaloz/mwlwifi/blob/master/core.c#L825
kaloz/mwlwifi#162
https://www.gargoyle-router.com/phpbb/viewtopic.php?f=11&t=11947

@obsy I'd appreciate your comments/testing on this one if you have the time please. I don't know if you have any mvebu devices, but specifically it would be great to test it on some non-mvebu devices as well to make sure it all still behaves.

column13: Update set_kernel_timezone to fix intermittent fails
column20:
Sometimes set_kernel_timezone doesn't seem to actually do anything... this was raised in the forum here:
https://www.gargoyle-router.com/phpbb/viewtopic.php?f=6&t=11955
A test scenario which produces the bug (most of the time...) was raised here:
https://www.gargoyle-router.com/phpbb/viewtopic.php?f=6&t=11955&start=10#p52776
This fix seems to make set_kernel_timezone more reliable. I can't pick why or how though, so am cautious of including it into the code without more user testing.
@ericpaulbishop , i'd appreciate an opinion on this one if you've got some time please.

column21: Seems reasonable. My one comment is that I'm not sure why the "warp_clock" behavior was getting triggered given that according to https://linux.die.net/man/2/settimeofday, it gets triggered when the tv arg is NULL, which it wasn't in the original code (it was being loaded from current). If calling it first with 0 tz_minuteswest like you are in the new version, then calling it again demonstrably fixes (or dramatically reduces the prevelance of) the issue that's probably a good solution.

column13: Update set_kernel_timezone to fix intermittent fails
column20:
Sometimes set_kernel_timezone doesn't seem to actually do anything... this was raised in the forum here:
https://www.gargoyle-router.com/phpbb/viewtopic.php?f=6&t=11955
A test scenario which produces the bug (most of the time...) was raised here:
https://www.gargoyle-router.com/phpbb/viewtopic.php?f=6&t=11955&start=10#p52776
This fix seems to make set_kernel_timezone more reliable. I can't pick why or how though, so am cautious of including it into the code without more user testing.
@ericpaulbishop , i'd appreciate an opinion on this one if you've got some time please.
column21:
Under Linux there are some peculiar "warp clock" semantics associated with the settimeofday() system call if on the very first call (after booting) that has a non-NULL tz argument, the tv argument is NULL and the tz_minuteswest field is nonzero. (The tz_dsttime field should be zero for this case.) In such a case it is assumed that the CMOS clock is on local time, and that it has to be incremented by this amount to get UTC system time. No doubt it is a bad idea to use this feature.

Noting the above, this is what the workaround is designed to do. We call it initially with everything zero'd to appease the kernel, and then call it again with the actual update. This should only be necessary on first boot, but we can't reliably tell if this will be the first time it is running on the system.
If we don't provide a timeval (null field) it should neither be updated nor returned so should be ok.
I think i'll merge it in later this week. Unfortunately we only ever get to test this piece of code a couple times a year.

column21:
Turns out my solution was causing a few issues due to it invoking the warp clock solution repeatedly.
It seems the original issue was that the wrapped functions for get/settimeofday were failing, and that changing these to syscalls is all that was needed to fix this.
Doh!

column13: Switch from popup windows to modals
column20:
The old method of generating popup windows to allow us to edit was great for its time (I really like the code behind it!), however it has a few drawbacks.

Not very mobile friendly
If the popup generates an alert window (or an ask message) and it is not the currently focused window, it will potentially be blocked leading to unexpected behaviour

This PR switches us to modals, which counter points 1 and 2 above. They do block the use of the remainder of the screen which is both good and bad. It users making edits to other parts when they shouldn't, but it stops users being able to navigate other pages to look for information. To this point, this activity is discouraged anyway as the GUI sometimes does not act favourably to opening the same page twice or the use of multiple tabs in general.
The other advantage is we gain more space in the rootfs, which is always an added bonus.
Size of /www/ before: 1724KB
Size of /www/ after: 1652KB
Diff: 72KB
(Ok, not huge, but at least heading in the right direction).

We've closed off the base_on_openwrt_remerge branch as it was merged into master, so please base your future contributions on that branch.

column20:
A Gargoyle variant of the popular "Travelmate" by Dirk Brenken @dibdot.
This is a rewrite of that application specifically for use with the Gargoyle web interface. Core differences include how the config files are used and some of the internal logic/features.
Some of these features will be reintroduced in subsequent versions after initial crowd testing.

In v1.1.0 the ability to scan for networks in range and add them without having to type out information manually will be introduced.
In v1.2.0 the ability to automatically scan and connect to open networks will be introduced.
In v1.3.0 the ability to check for internet connectivity on connection, and actively disconnect if it is not detected will be introduced.
This PR will sit open for a few days waiting feedback before i merge it.

column21: Yes thank you. In the past I had problems with it, I created the file using github - probably a bad choice, next time I create the file on my PC and have it copied (if it will be enough). Thanks again.

@obsy this looks like a bad fix. We don't grep the entire file, we just grep the output of json_get_keys BOARDKEYS, which does not contain ":" character or the literal quotation marks.
A better fix might be:
 json_load_file "/etc/board.json"
 json_get_keys BOARDKEYS
-SWITCHTEST=$(echo $BOARDKEYS | grep "switch")
+for KEY in $BOARDKEYS; do
+    [ "$KEY" = "switch" ] && SWITCHTEST="1"
+done
 [ -n "$SWITCHTEST" ] || exit 0
 
 json_select switch
Do you agree?
Looks good.
Thanks, i've pushed the fix
